ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This was my first time taking a workshop and I thought it was a great introduction to how the format works. As I learn more in my other classes, I hope to be more engaged.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I thought the tenor of the workshop was really great. Other workshops I attended were often combative and some of the participants were downright disrespectful. I was impressed that that was not at all the case in the IR workshop. The participants consistently offered thoughtful critiques without being rude. A weakness, though, was some of the subject matter of the workshop. It was very focused on political economy, which makes sense now but which I did not anticipate when I signed up for the workshop. Some of the work was so niche that I had a hard time understanding how it fit into broader IR research (the paper on medieval Florentine monetary policy stands out in this regard).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yeah. Good way to learn about other works in progress in the field and get a sense of how scholars analyze research.

Given my interests, I think I will probably sign up for the ISS workshop as my primary workshop next semester. However, I would definitely recommend the workshop to students interested in political economy and I plan to keep an eye on the upcoming presentations to keep attending on occasion.
